message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings, laboratory results, and symptoms suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is caused by a chromosomal anomaly where there is an extra X chromosome, resulting in XXY instead of the normal XY. In Klinefelter syndrome, there is an inactivated X-chromosome (Barr body) visible in cells. Therefore, the correct answer is (A). Absence of a barr body is seen in males, as they only have one X chromosome, while females have two X chromosomes, and one is inactivated. The absence of a second sex chromosome (C) and trisomy 13 (D) are not associated with Klinefelter syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings and laboratory tests suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with the presence of a barr body on cytogenetic testing. The absence of a barr body would indicate Turner syndrome. Absence of a second sex chromosome would indicate Turner or Klinefelter syndrome, but the physical exam findings suggest Klinefelter syndrome. Trisomy of chromosome 13 is associated with a different set of physical and developmental abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings, lab results, and presenting infertility suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is characterized by an extra X chromosome in males. This results in the presence of a Barr body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is characterized by a male having an extra X chromosome, resulting in XXY instead of the normal XY. This extra X chromosome can lead to the inactivation of one of the X chromosomes, resulting in the presence of a barr body. Option (A) is correct.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam findings and laboratory tests indicated that the male partner has Klinefelter syndrome, which is characterized by an extra X chromosome leading to the presence of a barr body. Absence of a barr body would indicate Turner syndrome, absence of a second sex chromosome, or a sex chromosome abnormality. Trisomy of chromosome 13 is associated with Patau syndrome and would not be relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical characteristics of the male partner suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is caused by an extra X chromosome (XXY). This leads to the presence of a barr body in the nuclei of cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the male partner suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is caused by an extra X chromosome. This extra X chromosome can cause the formation of a Barr body, which is an inactivated X chromosome. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Presence of a barr body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the male partner suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is characterized by an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY karyotype). In individuals with Klinefelter syndrome, a barr body would be present due to the inactivation of one of the X chromosomes in each cell. Therefore, the correct answer is (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical and laboratory findings suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is caused by an extra X chromosome. In individuals with this syndrome, there is an inactivated X chromosome in each cell, forming a Barr body. Therefore, the correct answer is (A). Absence of a Barr body is seen in males with XYY syndrome, absence of a second sex chromosome is seen in Turner syndrome, and trisomy of chromosome 13 is seen in Patau syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the male partner suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which is caused by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (XXY). This also leads to the presence of a barr body, which is a condensed, inactive X chromosome visible in the nuclei of cells in females and males with Klinefelter syndrome.
